content: The "Save America's Jobs Act of 2002" prevents corporate expatriation to avoid US income tax. The "Save America's Jobs Act of 2002" addresses corporate expatriation to prevent tax avoidance. It amends the definition of "domestic" in the Internal Revenue Code to include corporations or partnerships created or organized in the United States. In a corporate expatriation transaction, the acquiring corporation is treated as a domestic corporation. The "Save America's Jobs Act of 2002" addresses corporate expatriation to prevent tax avoidance by defining a corporate expatriation transaction as when a nominally foreign acquiring corporation obtains substantially all properties of a domestic corporation. The "Save America's Jobs Act of 2002" aims to prevent tax avoidance through corporate expatriation. It states that in a corporate expatriation transaction, if over 80% of the acquiring corporation's stock is held by former shareholders of the domestic corporation, a lower ownership requirement of 50% applies to a nominally foreign corporation with limited business activities. The "Save America's Jobs Act of 2002" addresses tax avoidance through corporate expatriation. It includes provisions for transactions involving nominally foreign corporations with limited business activities in a foreign country or publicly traded stock in the US. The "Save America's Jobs Act of 2002" aims to prevent tax avoidance by corporations through expatriation. It focuses on transactions where an acquiring corporation obtains properties of a domestic partnership and former partners hold over 80% of the acquiring corporation's stock post-transaction. The "Save America's Jobs Act of 2002" targets tax avoidance by corporations through expatriation. It includes rules for transactions involving an acquiring corporation and former partners holding over 80% of its stock post-transaction. The "Save America's Jobs Act of 2002" addresses tax avoidance by corporations through expatriation, defining terms like "nominally foreign corporation" and "expanded affiliated group." These definitions are crucial for determining ownership and preventing tax evasion. The Secretary of the Treasury will adjust corporate tax rates to offset revenue changes due to amendments. Estimates will be used, and adjustments made for future years based on prior revenue estimates. Effective dates for these changes are specified. The amendment regarding corporate expatriation transactions applies to those completed after September 11, 2001. There is a special rule for transactions completed on or before that date, which applies to taxable years of the acquiring corporation starting after December 31, 2003.
